qas.question: Does cell division end in plants?
What happens when a plant remains totipotent?

answers.text: ability to give rise to a new individual plant

qas.question: Why do phloem sieve tubes stop forming?
Why are plants able to stop and start dividing cells?
Are lignified cells able to continue dividing?

context: Unlike animals, many plant cells, particularly those of the parenchyma, do not terminally differentiate, <a0_0>remaining totipotent<a0_0/> with the <a1_0>ability to give rise to a new individual plant<a1_0/>. Exceptions include highly lignified cells, the sclerenchyma and xylem which are <a4_0>dead at maturity<a4_0/>, and the phloem sieve tubes which <a2_0>lack nuclei<a2_0/>. While plants use many of the same epigenetic mechanisms as animals, such as chromatin remodeling, an alternative hypothesis is that plants set their gene expression patterns using positional <a3_0>information from the environment<a3_0/> and surrounding cells to determine their developmental fate.
